summary: The case concerns two Belgian nationals, Dr. Alfred Albert and Dr. Herman Le Compte, who lodged applications with the European Commission of Human Rights in 1975 and 1976, respectively, alleging violations of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) by the Belgian government. The European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) held that there had been a breach of Article 6 para. 1 (art. 6-1) of the Convention in that the Appeals Council of the Ordre des médecins had not heard the applicants' cases publicly and had not pronounced its judgment publicly. The Court will now consider the application of Article 50 in the present case and determine the award of just satisfaction to the applicants. Dr. Le Compte's counsel had asked the Court to afford his client just satisfaction under Article 50, but the Commission's Delegates requested the Court to defer ruling on this point in the absence of any indication from Dr. Albert or his counsel. The Court will consider the claims made by Dr. Le Compte's lawyer, including the adoption by the Government of measures providing partial reparation and compensation for the prejudice suffered. The Court will determine the award of just satisfaction to the applicants, taking into account the facts and circumstances of the case.

2. The ECtHR is not only finding a violation of the Convention but is also considering the application of Article 50, which governs the awards of just satisfaction to applicants. This aspect of the case is relatively novel and may contribute to the development of case law in this area.
3. The case involves a discussion of the claims made by Dr. Le Compte's lawyer, including the adoption of measures providing partial reparation and compensation for the prejudice suffered. This adds a practical dimension to the case, as it involves the determination of the specific remedies to be awarded to the applicants.
4. While the case does not revolutionize existing case law or significantly contribute to its development, it does demonstrate the ECtHR's application of established principles to a specific set of facts. This adds to the case's medium importance, as it shows the Court's ability to consistently apply its case law.

In summary, while the case does not make a significant contribution to the development of ECtHR case law, it does go beyond merely applying existing case law and involves a novel application of Article 50. The practical aspect of determining the award of just satisfaction to the applicants also adds to the case's medium importance.
